00008 # *** Don't declare any lexicals above this point ***
00009 #
00010 # This function should return a closure which contains an eval that can't
00011 # see any lexicals in scope (apart from __ExPr__ which is unavoidable)
00012 
00013 sub lexless_anon_sub {
00014          # $_[0] is package;
00015          # $_[1] is strict flag;
00016     my $__ExPr__ = $_[2];   # must be a lexical to create the closure that
00017                 # can be used to pass the value into the safe
00018                 # world
00019 
00020     # Create anon sub ref in root of compartment.
00021     # Uses a closure (on $__ExPr__) to pass in the code to be executed.
00022     # (eval on one line to keep line numbers as expected by caller)
00023     eval sprintf
00024     'package %s; %s strict; sub { @_=(); eval q[my $__ExPr__;] . $__ExPr__; }',
00025         $_[0], $_[1] ? 'use' : 'no';
00026 }

00039 *ops_to_opset = \&opset;   # Temporary alias for old Penguins

00042 my $default_root  = 0;
00043 # share *_ and functions defined in universal.c
00044 # Don't share stuff like *UNIVERSAL:: otherwise code from the
00045 # compartment can 0wn functions in UNIVERSAL
00046 my $default_share = [qw[
00047     *_
00048     &PerlIO::get_layers
00049     &UNIVERSAL::isa
00050     &UNIVERSAL::can
00051     &UNIVERSAL::VERSION
00052     &utf8::is_utf8
00053     &utf8::valid
00054     &utf8::encode
00055     &utf8::decode
00056     &utf8::upgrade
00057     &utf8::downgrade
00058     &utf8::native_to_unicode
00059     &utf8::unicode_to_native
00060 ], ($] >= 5.008001 && qw[
00061     &Regexp::DESTROY
00062 ]), ($] >= 5.010 && qw[
00063     &re::is_regexp
00064     &re::regname
00065     &re::regnames
00066     &re::regnames_count
00067     &Tie::Hash::NamedCapture::FETCH
00068     &Tie::Hash::NamedCapture::STORE
00069     &Tie::Hash::NamedCapture::DELETE
00070     &Tie::Hash::NamedCapture::CLEAR
00071     &Tie::Hash::NamedCapture::EXISTS
00072     &Tie::Hash::NamedCapture::FIRSTKEY
00073     &Tie::Hash::NamedCapture::NEXTKEY
00074     &Tie::Hash::NamedCapture::SCALAR
00075     &Tie::Hash::NamedCapture::flags
00076     &UNIVERSAL::DOES
00077     &version::()
00078     &version::new
00079     &version::(""
00080     &version::stringify
00081     &version::(0+
00082     &version::numify
00083     &version::normal
00084     &version::(cmp
00085     &version::(<=>
00086     &version::vcmp
00087     &version::(bool
00088     &version::boolean
00089     &version::(nomethod
00090     &version::noop
00091     &version::is_alpha
00092     &version::qv
00093 ]), ($] >= 5.011 && qw[
00094     &re::regexp_pattern
00095 ])];

00097 sub new {
00098     my($class, $root, $mask) = @_;
00099     my $obj = {};
00100     bless $obj, $class;
00101 
00102     if (defined($root)) {
00103     croak "Can't use \"$root\" as root name"
00104         if $root =~ /^main\b/ or $root !~ /^\w[:\w]*$/;
00105     $obj->{Root}  = $root;
00106     $obj->{Erase} = 0;
00107     }
00108     else {
00109     $obj->{Root}  = "Safe::Root".$default_root++;
00110     $obj->{Erase} = 1;
00111     }
00112 
00113     # use permit/deny methods instead till interface issues resolved
00114     # XXX perhaps new Safe 'Root', mask => $mask, foo => bar, ...;
00115     croak "Mask parameter to new no longer supported" if defined $mask;
00116     $obj->permit_only(':default');
00117 
00118     # We must share $_ and @_ with the compartment or else ops such
00119     # as split, length and so on won't default to $_ properly, nor
00120     # will passing argument to subroutines work (via @_). In fact,
00121     # for reasons I don't completely understand, we need to share
00122     # the whole glob *_ rather than $_ and @_ separately, otherwise
00123     # @_ in non default packages within the compartment don't work.
00124     $obj->share_from('main', $default_share);
00125     Opcode::_safe_pkg_prep($obj->{Root}) if($Opcode::VERSION > 1.04);
00126     return $obj;
00127 }
00128 
00129 sub DESTROY {
00130     my $obj = shift;
00131     $obj->erase('DESTROY') if $obj->{Erase};
00132 }
00133 
00134 sub erase {
00135     my ($obj, $action) = @_;
00136     my $pkg = $obj->root();
00137     my ($stem, $leaf);
00138 
00139     no strict 'refs';
00140     $pkg = "main::$pkg\::"; # expand to full symbol table name
00141     ($stem, $leaf) = $pkg =~ m/(.*::)(\w+::)$/;
00142 
00143     # The 'my $foo' is needed! Without it you get an
00144     # 'Attempt to free unreferenced scalar' warning!
00145     my $stem_symtab = *{$stem}{HASH};
00146 
00147     #warn "erase($pkg) stem=$stem, leaf=$leaf";
00148     #warn " stem_symtab hash ".scalar(%$stem_symtab)."\n";
00149     # ", join(', ', %$stem_symtab),"\n";
00150 
00151 #    delete $stem_symtab->{$leaf};
00152 
00153     my $leaf_glob   = $stem_symtab->{$leaf};
00154     my $leaf_symtab = *{$leaf_glob}{HASH};
00155 #    warn " leaf_symtab ", join(', ', %$leaf_symtab),"\n";
00156     %$leaf_symtab = ();
00157     #delete $leaf_symtab->{'__ANON__'};
00158     #delete $leaf_symtab->{'foo'};
00159     #delete $leaf_symtab->{'main::'};
00160 #    my $foo = undef ${"$stem\::"}{"$leaf\::"};
00161 
00162     if ($action and $action eq 'DESTROY') {
00163         delete $stem_symtab->{$leaf};
00164     } else {
00165         $obj->share_from('main', $default_share);
00166     }
00167     1;
00168 }
00169

00171 sub reinit {
00172     my $obj= shift;
00173     $obj->erase;
00174     $obj->share_redo;
00175 }
00176 
00177 sub root {
00178     my $obj = shift;
00179     croak("Safe root method now read-only") if @_;
00180     return $obj->{Root};
00181 }
00182 
00183 
00184 sub mask {
00185     my $obj = shift;
00186     return $obj->{Mask} unless @_;
00187     $obj->deny_only(@_);
00188 }
00189 
00190 # v1 compatibility methods
00191 sub trap   { shift->deny(@_)   }
00192 sub untrap { shift->permit(@_) }
00193 
00194 sub deny {
00195     my $obj = shift;
00196     $obj->{Mask} |= opset(@_);
00197 }
00198 sub deny_only {
00199     my $obj = shift;
00200     $obj->{Mask} = opset(@_);
00201 }
00202 
00203 sub permit {
00204     my $obj = shift;
00205     # XXX needs testing
00206     $obj->{Mask} &= invert_opset opset(@_);
00207 }
00208 sub permit_only {
00209     my $obj = shift;
00210     $obj->{Mask} = invert_opset opset(@_);
00211 }
00212 
00213 
00214 sub dump_mask {
00215     my $obj = shift;
00216     print opset_to_hex($obj->{Mask}),"\n";
00217 }

00220 
00221 sub share {
00222     my($obj, @vars) = @_;
00223     $obj->share_from(scalar(caller), \@vars);
00224 }
00225 
00226 sub share_from {
00227     my $obj = shift;
00228     my $pkg = shift;
00229     my $vars = shift;
00230     my $no_record = shift || 0;
00231     my $root = $obj->root();
00232     croak("vars not an array ref") unless ref $vars eq 'ARRAY';
00233     no strict 'refs';
00234     # Check that 'from' package actually exists
00235     croak("Package \"$pkg\" does not exist")
00236     unless keys %{"$pkg\::"};
00237     my $arg;
00238     foreach $arg (@$vars) {
00239     # catch some $safe->share($var) errors:
00240     my ($var, $type);
00241     $type = $1 if ($var = $arg) =~ s/^(\W)//;
00242     # warn "share_from $pkg $type $var";
00243     *{$root."::$var"} = (!$type)       ? \&{$pkg."::$var"}
00244               : ($type eq '&') ? \&{$pkg."::$var"}
00245               : ($type eq '$') ? \${$pkg."::$var"}
00246               : ($type eq '@') ? \@{$pkg."::$var"}
00247               : ($type eq '%') ? \%{$pkg."::$var"}
00248               : ($type eq '*') ?  *{$pkg."::$var"}
00249               : croak(qq(Can't share "$type$var" of unknown type));
00250     }
00251     $obj->share_record($pkg, $vars) unless $no_record or !$vars;
00252 }
00253 
00254 sub share_record {
00255     my $obj = shift;
00256     my $pkg = shift;
00257     my $vars = shift;
00258     my $shares = \%{$obj->{Shares} ||= {}};
00259     # Record shares using keys of $obj->{Shares}. See reinit.
00260     @{$shares}{@$vars} = ($pkg) x @$vars if @$vars;
00261 }
00262 sub share_redo {
00263     my $obj = shift;
00264     my $shares = \%{$obj->{Shares} ||= {}};
00265     my($var, $pkg);
00266     while(($var, $pkg) = each %$shares) {
00267     # warn "share_redo $pkg\:: $var";
00268     $obj->share_from($pkg,  [ $var ], 1);
00269     }
00270 }
00271 sub share_forget {
00272     delete shift->{Shares};
00273 }
00274 
00275 sub varglob {
00276     my ($obj, $var) = @_;
00277     no strict 'refs';
00278     return *{$obj->root()."::$var"};
00279 }
00280 
00281 
00282 sub reval {
00283     my ($obj, $expr, $strict) = @_;
00284     my $root = $obj->{Root};
00285 
00286     my $evalsub = lexless_anon_sub($root,$strict, $expr);
00287     return Opcode::_safe_call_sv($root, $obj->{Mask}, $evalsub);
00288 }
00289 
00290 sub rdo {
00291     my ($obj, $file) = @_;
00292     my $root = $obj->{Root};
00293 
00294     my $evalsub = eval
00295         sprintf('package %s; sub { @_ = (); do $file }', $root);
00296     return Opcode::_safe_call_sv($root, $obj->{Mask}, $evalsub);
00297 }

00300 1;

00302 __END__
00303 
00304 =head1 NAME
00305 
00306 Safe - Compile and execute code in restricted compartments
00307 
00308 =head1 SYNOPSIS
00309 
00310   use WWSafe;
00311 
00312   $compartment = new Safe;
00313 
00314   $compartment->permit(qw(time sort :browse));
00315 
00316   $result = $compartment->reval($unsafe_code);
00317 
00318 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00319 
00320 The Safe extension module allows the creation of compartments
00321 in which perl code can be evaluated. Each compartment has
00322 
00323 =over 8
00324 
00325 =item a new namespace
00326 
00327 The "root" of the namespace (i.e. "main::") is changed to a
00328 different package and code evaluated in the compartment cannot
00329 refer to variables outside this namespace, even with run-time
00330 glob lookups and other tricks.
00331 
00332 Code which is compiled outside the compartment can choose to place
00333 variables into (or I<share> variables with) the compartment's namespace
00334 and only that data will be visible to code evaluated in the
00335 compartment.
00336 
00337 By default, the only variables shared with compartments are the
00338 "underscore" variables $_ and @_ (and, technically, the less frequently
00339 used %_, the _ filehandle and so on). This is because otherwise perl
00340 operators which default to $_ will not work and neither will the
00341 assignment of arguments to @_ on subroutine entry.
00342 
00343 =item an operator mask
00344 
00345 Each compartment has an associated "operator mask". Recall that
00346 perl code is compiled into an internal format before execution.
00347 Evaluating perl code (e.g. via "eval" or "do 'file'") causes
00348 the code to be compiled into an internal format and then,
00349 provided there was no error in the compilation, executed.
00350 Code evaluated in a compartment compiles subject to the
00351 compartment's operator mask. Attempting to evaluate code in a
00352 compartment which contains a masked operator will cause the
00353 compilation to fail with an error. The code will not be executed.
00354 
00355 The default operator mask for a newly created compartment is
00356 the ':default' optag.
00357 
00358 It is important that you read the L<Opcode> module documentation
00359 for more information, especially for detailed definitions of opnames,
00360 optags and opsets.
00361 
00362 Since it is only at the compilation stage that the operator mask
00363 applies, controlled access to potentially unsafe operations can
00364 be achieved by having a handle to a wrapper subroutine (written
00365 outside the compartment) placed into the compartment. For example,
00366 
00367     $cpt = new Safe;
00368     sub wrapper {
00369         # vet arguments and perform potentially unsafe operations
00370     }
00371     $cpt->share('&wrapper');
00372 
00373 =back
00374 
00375 
00376 =head1 WARNING
00377 
00378 The authors make B<no warranty>, implied or otherwise, about the
00379 suitability of this software for safety or security purposes.
00380 
00381 The authors shall not in any case be liable for special, incidental,
00382 consequential, indirect or other similar damages arising from the use
00383 of this software.
00384 
00385 Your mileage will vary. If in any doubt B<do not use it>.
00386 
00387 
00388 =head2 RECENT CHANGES
00389 
00390 The interface to the Safe module has changed quite dramatically since
00391 version 1 (as supplied with Perl5.002). Study these pages carefully if
00392 you have code written to use Safe version 1 because you will need to
00393 makes changes.
00394 
00395 
00396 =head2 Methods in class Safe
00397 
00398 To create a new compartment, use
00399 
00400     $cpt = new Safe;
00401 
00402 Optional argument is (NAMESPACE), where NAMESPACE is the root namespace
00403 to use for the compartment (defaults to "Safe::Root0", incremented for
00404 each new compartment).
00405 
00406 Note that version 1.00 of the Safe module supported a second optional
00407 parameter, MASK.  That functionality has been withdrawn pending deeper
00408 consideration. Use the permit and deny methods described below.
00409 
00410 The following methods can then be used on the compartment
00411 object returned by the above constructor. The object argument
00412 is implicit in each case.
00413 
00414 
00415 =over 8
00416 
00417 =item permit (OP, ...)
00418 
00419 Permit the listed operators to be used when compiling code in the
00420 compartment (in I<addition> to any operators already permitted).
00421 
00422 You can list opcodes by names, or use a tag name; see
00423 L<Opcode/"Predefined Opcode Tags">.
00424 
00425 =item permit_only (OP, ...)
00426 
00427 Permit I<only> the listed operators to be used when compiling code in
00428 the compartment (I<no> other operators are permitted).
00429 
00430 =item deny (OP, ...)
00431 
00432 Deny the listed operators from being used when compiling code in the
00433 compartment (other operators may still be permitted).
00434 
00435 =item deny_only (OP, ...)
00436 
00437 Deny I<only> the listed operators from being used when compiling code
00438 in the compartment (I<all> other operators will be permitted).
00439 
00440 =item trap (OP, ...)
00441 
00442 =item untrap (OP, ...)
00443 
00444 The trap and untrap methods are synonyms for deny and permit
00445 respectfully.
00446 
00447 =item share (NAME, ...)
00448 
00449 This shares the variable(s) in the argument list with the compartment.
00450 This is almost identical to exporting variables using the L<Exporter>
00451 module.
00452 
00453 Each NAME must be the B<name> of a non-lexical variable, typically
00454 with the leading type identifier included. A bareword is treated as a
00455 function name.
00456 
00457 Examples of legal names are '$foo' for a scalar, '@foo' for an
00458 array, '%foo' for a hash, '&foo' or 'foo' for a subroutine and '*foo'
00459 for a glob (i.e.  all symbol table entries associated with "foo",
00460 including scalar, array, hash, sub and filehandle).
00461 
00462 Each NAME is assumed to be in the calling package. See share_from
00463 for an alternative method (which share uses).
00464 
00465 =item share_from (PACKAGE, ARRAYREF)
00466 
00467 This method is similar to share() but allows you to explicitly name the
00468 package that symbols should be shared from. The symbol names (including
00469 type characters) are supplied as an array reference.
00470 
00471     $safe->share_from('main', [ '$foo', '%bar', 'func' ]);
00472 
00473 
00474 =item varglob (VARNAME)
00475 
00476 This returns a glob reference for the symbol table entry of VARNAME in
00477 the package of the compartment. VARNAME must be the B<name> of a
00478 variable without any leading type marker. For example,
00479 
00480     $cpt = new Safe 'Root';
00481     $Root::foo = "Hello world";
00482     # Equivalent version which doesn't need to know $cpt's package name:
00483     ${$cpt->varglob('foo')} = "Hello world";
00484 
00485 
00486 =item reval (STRING)
00487 
00488 This evaluates STRING as perl code inside the compartment.
00489 
00490 The code can only see the compartment's namespace (as returned by the
00491 B<root> method). The compartment's root package appears to be the
00492 C<main::> package to the code inside the compartment.
00493 
00494 Any attempt by the code in STRING to use an operator which is not permitted
00495 by the compartment will cause an error (at run-time of the main program
00496 but at compile-time for the code in STRING).  The error is of the form
00497 "'%s' trapped by operation mask...".
00498 
00499 If an operation is trapped in this way, then the code in STRING will
00500 not be executed. If such a trapped operation occurs or any other
00501 compile-time or return error, then $@ is set to the error message, just
00502 as with an eval().
00503 
00504 If there is no error, then the method returns the value of the last
00505 expression evaluated, or a return statement may be used, just as with
00506 subroutines and B<eval()>. The context (list or scalar) is determined
00507 by the caller as usual.
00508 
00509 This behaviour differs from the beta distribution of the Safe extension
00510 where earlier versions of perl made it hard to mimic the return
00511 behaviour of the eval() command and the context was always scalar.
00512 
00513 Some points to note:
00514 
00515 If the entereval op is permitted then the code can use eval "..." to
00516 'hide' code which might use denied ops. This is not a major problem
00517 since when the code tries to execute the eval it will fail because the
00518 opmask is still in effect. However this technique would allow clever,
00519 and possibly harmful, code to 'probe' the boundaries of what is
00520 possible.
00521 
00522 Any string eval which is executed by code executing in a compartment,
00523 or by code called from code executing in a compartment, will be eval'd
00524 in the namespace of the compartment. This is potentially a serious
00525 problem.
00526 
00527 Consider a function foo() in package pkg compiled outside a compartment
00528 but shared with it. Assume the compartment has a root package called
00529 'Root'. If foo() contains an eval statement like eval '$foo = 1' then,
00530 normally, $pkg::foo will be set to 1.  If foo() is called from the
00531 compartment (by whatever means) then instead of setting $pkg::foo, the
00532 eval will actually set $Root::pkg::foo.
00533 
00534 This can easily be demonstrated by using a module, such as the Socket
00535 module, which uses eval "..." as part of an AUTOLOAD function. You can
00536 'use' the module outside the compartment and share an (autoloaded)
00537 function with the compartment. If an autoload is triggered by code in
00538 the compartment, or by any code anywhere that is called by any means
00539 from the compartment, then the eval in the Socket module's AUTOLOAD
00540 function happens in the namespace of the compartment. Any variables
00541 created or used by the eval'd code are now under the control of
00542 the code in the compartment.
00543 
00544 A similar effect applies to I<all> runtime symbol lookups in code
00545 called from a compartment but not compiled within it.
00546 
00547 
00548 
00549 =item rdo (FILENAME)
00550 
00551 This evaluates the contents of file FILENAME inside the compartment.
00552 See above documentation on the B<reval> method for further details.
00553 
00554 =item root (NAMESPACE)
00555 
00556 This method returns the name of the package that is the root of the
00557 compartment's namespace.
00558 
00559 Note that this behaviour differs from version 1.00 of the Safe module
00560 where the root module could be used to change the namespace. That
00561 functionality has been withdrawn pending deeper consideration.
00562 
00563 =item mask (MASK)
00564 
00565 This is a get-or-set method for the compartment's operator mask.
00566 
00567 With no MASK argument present, it returns the current operator mask of
00568 the compartment.
00569 
00570 With the MASK argument present, it sets the operator mask for the
00571 compartment (equivalent to calling the deny_only method).
00572 
00573 =back
00574 
00575 
00576 =head2 Some Safety Issues
00577 
00578 This section is currently just an outline of some of the things code in
00579 a compartment might do (intentionally or unintentionally) which can
00580 have an effect outside the compartment.
00581 
00582 =over 8
00583 
00584 =item Memory
00585 
00586 Consuming all (or nearly all) available memory.
00587 
00588 =item CPU
00589 
00590 Causing infinite loops etc.
00591 
00592 =item Snooping
00593 
00594 Copying private information out of your system. Even something as
00595 simple as your user name is of value to others. Much useful information
00596 could be gleaned from your environment variables for example.
00597 
00598 =item Signals
00599 
00600 Causing signals (especially SIGFPE and SIGALARM) to affect your process.
00601 
00602 Setting up a signal handler will need to be carefully considered
00603 and controlled.  What mask is in effect when a signal handler
00604 gets called?  If a user can get an imported function to get an
00605 exception and call the user's signal handler, does that user's
00606 restricted mask get re-instated before the handler is called?
00607 Does an imported handler get called with its original mask or
00608 the user's one?
00609 
00610 =item State Changes
00611 
00612 Ops such as chdir obviously effect the process as a whole and not just
00613 the code in the compartment. Ops such as rand and srand have a similar
00614 but more subtle effect.
00615 
00616 =back
00617

00619

00621

00623

00625
